spirit:abstractionDefinition.spirit:name: ACE5-LiteDVM_rtl

spirit:port.spirit:description: Synchronous signals are sampled on the rising edge of the global clock.

Clock enable signal. Used as a qualifier for the ACLK signal. This signal indicates which rising edges of ACLK should be acted upon: 0 = any rising edge of ACLK should be ignored 1 = valid rising edge of ACLK
Check signal for ACLKEN.
Active-LOW global reset signal.
Asserted high to indicate that the signals on the AW channel are valid.
Asserted high to indicate that a transfer on the AW channel can be accepted.
Asserted HIGH to indicate that a transfer might occur in the following cycle.
Asserted HIGH to give one AW credit on the respective RP.
Asserted HIGH to give one shared AW credit, supports up to one shared credit per cycle.
Encoded indicator of the Resource Plane number for an AW transfer.
Asserted HIGH to indicate that an AW transfer is using a shared credit.
Transaction identifier used for the ordering of write requests.
Address of first transfer in a transaction.
A 4-bit region identifier which can be used to identify different address regions.
The total number of transfers in a transaction, encoded as: Length = AxLEN + 1.
Indicates the maximum number of bytes in each data transfer within a transaction.
Describes how the address increments between transfers in a transaction.
Asserted high to indicate that an exclusive access is required.
The memory attributes of a request control how a transaction progresses through the system and how caches and buffers handle the request.
The Access attributes for a request which can be used to protect memory against unexpected transactions.
Extends the physical address spaces that can be addressed to include Root and Realm.
Physical address space (PAS) of a transaction.
LOW to indicate this is a data access, HIGH for an instruction access.
LOW to indicate this is an unprivileged access, HIGH for a privileged access.
Quality of Service identifier used to distinguish between different traffic streams.
User-defined extension to a request.
Shareability domain of a request.
Opcode for requests using the write channels.
Node Identifier of the target for a stash operation.
HIGH to indicate that the AWSTASHNID signal is valid.
Logical Processor Identifier within the target for a stash operation.
HIGH to indicate that the AWSTASHLPID signal is valid.
Trace signal associated with the write request channel.
A user-defined value that must be reflected from a write request to response transfers.
MMU qualifier signal. When deasserted, the transaction address is a physical address and does not require translation.
Secure Stream Identifier for untranslated transactions.
Stream Identifier for untranslated transactions.
Asserted HIGH to indicate that a transaction has a valid substream identifier.
Substream identifier for untranslated transactions.
Indicates that the transaction has already undergone PCIe ATS translation.
Indicates the SMMU flow for managing translation faults for this transaction.
HIGH to indicate that there is no PAS expectation
Protected Mode indicator
A 4b user-defined descriptor associated with a translation table entry that can be annotated onto a transaction request.
RME Memory Encryption Context identifier (MECID).
Non-secure access identifier, can be checked to permit or deny access to a memory location.
Subsystem identifier that indicates from which subsystem a request originates.
Indicates the type and endianness of an atomic transaction.
Memory System Resource Partitioning and Monitoring (MPAM) information for a request.
If asserted high, the ID for this transfer is unique-in-flight.
Indicates the CMO type for write opcodes that include a cache maintenance operation.
Indicates if MTE tags are associated with a write transaction.
ACT payload on the write request channel.
Asserted HIGH to indicate that this is a WriteACT request and AWACT contains a valid payload.
Check signal for AWVALID.
Check signal for AWREADY.
Check signal for AWPENDING.
Check signal for AWCRDT.
Check signal for AWCRDTSH.
Check signal for AWRP.
Check signal for AWSHAREDCRD.
Check signal for AWID, AWIDUNQ.
Check signal for AWADDR.
Check signal for AWLEN.
Check signal for AWSIZE, AWBURST, AWLOCK, AWPROT, AWNSE.
Check signal for AWREGION, AWCACHE, AWQOS.
Check signal for AWDOMAIN, AWSNOOP.
Check signal for AWATOP, AWCMO, AWTAGOP.
Check signal for AWPAS.
Check signal for AWINST and AWPRIV.
Check signal for AWUSER.
Check signal for AWSTASHNID, AWSTASHNIDEN.
Check signal for AWSTASHLPID, AWSTASHLPIDEN.
Check signal for AWTRACE.
Check signal for AWLOOP.
Check signal for AWMMUATST, AWMMUFLOW, AWMMUSECSID, AWMMUSSIDV, AWMMUVALID.
Check signal for AWMMUSID.
Check signal for AWMMUSSID.
Check signal for AWMMUPASUNKNOWN
Check signal for AWMMUPM
Check signal for AWPBHA.
Check signal for AWMECID.
Check signal for AWNSAID.
Check signal for AWMPAM.
Check signal for AWSUBSYSID.
Check signal for AWACTV and AWACT.
Asserted high to indicate that the signals on the W channel are valid.
Asserted high to indicate that a transfer on the W channel can be accepted.
Asserted HIGH to indicate that a transfer might occur in the following cycle.
Asserted HIGH to give one W credit on the respective RP.
Asserted HIGH to give one shared W credit, supports up to one shared credit per cycle.
Encoded indicator of the Resource Plane number for a W transfer.
Asserted HIGH to indicate that a W transfer is using a shared credit.
The write data signal carries data between a Manager and Subordinate in a write transaction.
Indicates which byte lanes of WDATA contain valid data in a write transaction.

Memory tag associated with data. There is a 4-bit tag per 128-bits of data, with a minimum of 4-bits. It has the same validity rules as the associated data. It is recommended that invalid tags are driven to zero.
Indicates which tags must be written to memory when AWTAGOP is Update. There is 1 bit per 4 bits of tag.
Indicates the last write data transfer of a transaction.
User-defined extension to write data.
Asserted high to indicate that the data in this transfer is corrupted. There is one bit per 64-bits of data.
Trace signal associated with the write data channel.
Check signal for WVALID.
Check signal for WREADY.
Check signal for WPENDING.
Check signal for WCRDT.
Check signal for WCRDTSH.
Check signal for WRP.
Check signal for WSHAREDCRD.
Check signal for WDATA.
Check signal for WSTRB.
Check signal for WTAG, WTAGUPDATE.
Check signal for WLAST.
Check signal for WUSER.
Check signal for WPOISON.
Check signal for WTRACE.
Asserted high to indicate that the signals on the B channel are valid.
Asserted high to indicate that a transfer on the B channel can be accepted.
Asserted HIGH to indicate that a transfer might occur in the following cycle.
Asserted HIGH to give one B credit.
Transaction identifier used for the ordering of write responses.
If asserted high, the ID for this transfer is unique-in-flight.
Indicates the result of a transaction that uses the write channels.
Asserted HIGH to indicate a Completion response.
Asserted HIGH to indicate a Persist response.
Indicates the result of a tag comparison on a write transaction.
User-defined extension to a write response.
Trace signal associated with the write response channel.
A user-defined value that is copied from the write request to write responses.
Indicates the current level of Subordinate activity in a transaction response. The value increases as the Subordinate becomes busier.
Check signal for BVALID.
Check signal for BREADY.
Check signal for BPENDING.
Check signal for BCRDT.
Check signal for BID, BIDUNQ.
Check signal for BRESP, BCOMP, BPERSIST, BTAGMATCH, BBUSY.
Check signal for BUSER.
Check signal for BTRACE.
Check signal for BLOOP.
Asserted high to indicate that the signals on the AR channel are valid.
Asserted high to indicate that a transfer on the AR channel can be accepted.
Asserted HIGH to indicate that a transfer might occur in the following cycle.
Asserted HIGH to give one AR credit on the respective RP.
Asserted HIGH to give one shared AR credit, supports up to one shared credit per cycle.
Encoded indicator of the Resource Plane number for an AR transfer.
Asserted HIGH to indicate that an AR transfer is using a shared credit.
Transaction identifier used for the ordering of read requests.
Address of first transfer in a transaction.
A 4-bit region identifier which can be used to identify different address regions.
The total number of transfers in a transaction, encoded as: Length = AxLEN + 1.
Indicates the maximum number of bytes in each data transfer within a transaction.
Describes how the address increments between transfers in a transaction.
Asserted high to indicate that an exclusive access is required.
The memory attributes of a request control how a transaction progresses through the system and how caches and buffers handle the request.
The Access attributes for a request which can be used to protect memory against unexpected transactions.
Extends the physical address spaces that can be addressed to include Root and Realm.
Physical address space (PAS) of a transaction.
LOW to indicate this is a data access, HIGH for an instruction access.
LOW to indicate this is an unprivileged access, HIGH for a privileged access.
Quality of Service identifier used to distinguish between different traffic streams.
User-defined extension to a request.
Shareability domain of a request.
Opcode for requests using the read channels.
Trace signal associated with the read request channel.
A user-defined value that must be reflected from a read request to response and data transfers.
MMU qualifier signal. When deasserted, the transaction address is a physical address and does not require translation.
Secure Stream Identifier for untranslated transactions.
Stream Identifier for untranslated transactions.
Asserted HIGH to indicate that a transaction has a valid substream identifier.
Substream identifier for untranslated transactions.
Indicates that the transaction has already undergone PCIe ATS translation.
Indicates the SMMU flow for managing translation faults for this transaction.
HIGH to indicate that there is no PAS expectation
Protected Mode indicator
A 4b user-defined descriptor associated with a translation table entry that can be annotated onto a transaction request.
RME Memory Encryption Context identifier (MECID).
Non-secure access identifier, can be checked to permit or deny access to a memory location.
Subsystem identifier that indicates from which subsystem a request originates.
Memory System Resource Partitioning and Monitoring (MPAM) information for a request.
If asserted in a read request, the Subordinate can send read data in 128b chunks.
If asserted high, the ID for this transfer is unique-in-flight.
Indicates if MTE tags are requested with a read transaction.
ACT payload on the read request channel.
Asserted HIGH to indicate that this is a ReadACT request and ARACT contains a valid payload.
Check signal for ARVALID.
Check signal for ARREADY.
Check signal for ARPENDING.
Check signal for ARCRDT.
Check signal for ARCRDTSH.
Check signal for ARRP.
Check signal for ARSHAREDCRD.
Check signal for ARID, ARIDUNQ.
Check signal for ARADDR.
Check signal for ARLEN.
Check signal for ARSIZE, ARBURST, ARLOCK, ARPROT, ARNSE.
Check signal for ARREGION, ARCACHE, ARQOS.
Check signal for ARDOMAIN, ARSNOOP.
Check signal for ARCHUNKEN, ARTAGOP.
Check signal for ARPAS.
Check signal for ARINST and ARPRIV.
Check signal for ARUSER.
Check signal for ARTRACE.
Check signal for ARLOOP.
Check signal for ARMMUATST, ARMMUFLOW, ARMMUSECSID, ARMMUSSIDV, ARMMUVALID.
Check signal for ARMMUSID.
Check signal for ARMMUSSID.
Check signal for ARMMUPASUNKNOWN
Check signal for ARMMUPM
Check signal for ARNSAID.
Check signal for ARMPAM.
Check signal for ARPBHA.
Check signal for ARMECID.
Check signal for ARSUBSYSID.
Check signal for ARACTV and ARACT.
Asserted high to indicate that the signals on the R channel are valid.
Asserted high to indicate that a transfer on the R channel can be accepted.
Asserted HIGH to indicate that a transfer might occur in the following cycle.
Asserted HIGH to give one R credit.
Transaction identifier used for the ordering of read data.
If asserted high, the ID for this transfer is unique-in-flight.
The read data signal carries data between a Subordinate and Manager in a read transaction.

Memory tag associated with data. There is a 4-bit tag per 128-bits of data, with a minimum of 4-bits. It has the same validity rules as the associated data. It is recommended that invalid tags are driven to zero.
Response for transactions on the read channels. Must be valid when RVALID is asserted.
Indicates the last read data transfer of a transaction.
User-defined extension to read data and response.
Asserted high to indicate that the data in this transfer is corrupted. There is one bit per 64-bits of data.
Trace signal associated with the read data channel.
A user-defined value that is copied from the read request to response and data transfers.
Asserted high to indicate that RCHUNKNUM and RCHUNKSTRB are valid. It must be the same for every response of the transaction.
Indicates the chunk number being transferred. Chunks are numbered incrementally from zero, according to the data width and base address of the transaction.

Indicates the read data chunks that are valid for this transfer. Each bit corresponds to 128 bits of data. The least significant bit of RCHUNKSTRB corresponds to the least significant 128 bits of RDATA.
Indicates the current level of Subordinate activity in a transaction response. The value increases as the Subordinate becomes busier.
Check signal for RVALID.
Check signal for RREADY.
Check signal for RPENDING.
Check signal for RCRDT.
Check signal for RID, RIDUNQ.
Check signal for RDATA.
Check signal for RTAG.
Check signal for RRESP, RBUSY.
Check signal for RLAST.
Check signal for RCHUNKV, RCHUNKNUM, RCHUNKSTRB.
Check signal for RUSER.
Check signal for RPOISON.
Check signal for RTRACE.
Check signal for RLOOP.
Asserted high to indicate that the signals on the AC channel are valid.
Asserted high to indicate that a transfer on the AC channel can be accepted.
Asserted HIGH to indicate that a transfer might occur in the following cycle.
Asserted HIGH to give one AC credit.
Used to carry the payload for DVM message requests.
Extension to support 16-bit VMID in DVM messages.
Trace signal associated with the snoop request channel.
Check signal for ACVALID.
Check signal for ACREADY.
Check signal for ACPENDING.
Check signal for ACCRDT.
Check signal for ACADDR.
Check signal for ACVMIDEXT.
Check signal for ACTRACE.
Asserted high to indicate that the signals on the CR channel are valid.
Asserted high to indicate that a transfer on the CR channel can be accepted.
Asserted HIGH to indicate that a transfer might occur in the following cycle.
Asserted HIGH to give one CR credit.
Trace signal associated with the snoop response channel.
Check signal for CRVALID.
Check signal for CRREADY.
Check signal for CRPENDING.
Check signal for CRCRDT.
Check signal for CRTRACE.
An output from a Subordinate that indicates the QoS value for which it accepts requests from the AW channel.
An output from a Subordinate that indicates the QoS value for which it accepts requests from the AR channel.
Check signal for VAWQOSACCEPT.
Check signal for VARQOSACCEPT.
Manager output, asserted HIGH to indicate there might be activity on the read and write request channels.
Subordinate output, asserted HIGH to indicate there might be activity on the snoop request channel.
Check signal for AWAKEUP.
Check signal for ACWAKEUP.
Activation / deactivation request from a Manager.
Activation / deactivation acknowledge from a Subordinate.
Asserted HIGH to indicate that the Subordinate wants the Manager to stop the interface.
Activation / deactivation request from a Subordinate for the snoop channels.
Activation / deactivation acknowledge from a Manager for the snoop channels.
Asserted HIGH to indicate that the Manager wants the Subordinate to stop the snoop channels.
Check signal for ACTIVATEREQ
Check signal for ACTIVATEACK
Check signal for ASKSTOP
Check signal for ACTIVATEREQD
Check signal for ACTIVATEACKD
Check signal for ASKSTOPD
Output from a Manager, asserted HIGH to request that it receives DVM messages on the AC channel.
Output from a Subordinate, asserted HIGH to acknowledge that the attached Manager might receive DVM messages on the AC channel.
Check signal for SYSCOREQ.
Check signal for SYSCOACK.
Manager tie-off input, used to control the issuing of Atomic transactions from an interface.
Manager tie-off input, used to control the issuing of Shareable transactions from an interface.
Manager tie-off input, used to control the issuing of CMOs from an interface.
Manager tie-off input, used to control the issuing of a CleanInvalidPoPA CMO.
Manager tie-off input, used to control the issuing of CleanSharedPersist and CleanSharedDeepPersist CMOs.
Manager tie-off input, used to control the issuing of a CleanInvalidStorage CMO.

spirit:abstractionDefinition.spirit:description: An ACE5-LiteDVM interface is an AXI5 variant intended to connect an MMU to a memory system. Reference: AMBA AXI Protocol Specification ARM IHI 0022 http://www.arm.com/support/AMBA.html

arm:channel.arm:name: AW_Channel
arm:channel.arm:label: AW
arm:channel.arm:description: The write request channel carries all the required address and control information for transactions using the write channels.

arm:channel.arm:name: W_Channel
arm:channel.arm:label: W
arm:channel.arm:description: The write data channel carries data for transactions using the write channels.

arm:channel.arm:name: B_Channel
arm:channel.arm:label: B
arm:channel.arm:description: The write response channel carries responses for transactions using the write channels.

arm:channel.arm:name: AR_Channel
arm:channel.arm:label: AR
arm:channel.arm:description: The read request channel carries all the required address and control information for transactions using the read channels.

arm:channel.arm:name: R_Channel
arm:channel.arm:label: R
arm:channel.arm:description: The read data channel carries data and responses for transactions using the read channels.

arm:channel.arm:name: AC_Channel
arm:channel.arm:label: AC
arm:channel.arm:description: The snoop request channel carries DVM message requests.

arm:channel.arm:name: CR_Channel
arm:channel.arm:label: CR
arm:channel.arm:description: The snoop response channel carries DVM message responses.
